column1: cherrytisane 159977609768 "2017-04-25 14:51:14 GMT" https://cherrytisane.tumblr.com/post/159977609768/why-does-drug-resistance-readily-evolve-but "drferox: animalsustainability:  Ever wondered why people are a lot more concerned about antibiotic resistance than vaccine resistance? Ever wondered why vaccines are one of our most important tools in the fight of disease and the prevention of more drug-resistant strains? Â This article does a great job of explaining how and why vaccine resistance is less of a threat
column2: and why vaccines are so important to preserving the efficacy of what drugs we do have available. Some Key PointsÂ  Vaccines act earlier than antibiotics
column3: meaning they can limit microbe replication and mutation sooner Vaccination suppresses peak microbial population size even if microbes try to infect the system (by 2-5 orders of magnitude in a rodent tuberculosis model
column4: for example) Vaccines severely reduce the opportunities for new drug resistant / vaccine resistant strains to arise or spread once arisen Vaccines expose the immune system to a wide variety of potential pathogen proteins and binding sites
column5: expanding the amount of pathogen-associated patterns the immune system can recognize.Â â€œThis means that immunity in effect is acting like combination therapyâ€ This is especially effective where the potential patterns of a pathogen are constrained by evolution
column6: limiting the number of patterns that could slip through the immune systemâ€™s surveillance Â Where vaccine resistance has evolved
column7: it was because one of the benefits identified in the article failed
column8: such as where mutation leads to further patterns that were not vaccinated against by the vaccine
column9: or where new strains not included in the new vaccine have arisen
column10: sometimes due to small mutations in the genetic code leading to large effects on the microbeâ€™s ability to escape detection (like some pertussis strains)
column11: or because the initial vaccine was able to prevent disease from getting worse
column12: but unable to completely prevent infection and transmission. Â Current vaccine research is working hard on addressing these issues Â When serotype (distinct strain) is vaccinated against
column13: the serotype may be replaced in the population by another
column14: which vaccines do not grant immunity to
column15: requiring the development of a new vaccine. While some vaccines protect against multiple serotypes (or all known serotypes of a disease)
column16: and most vaccines remain very effective
column17: current research is ongoing to understand how serotype diversity changes in response to vaccination so better vaccines can be created.  â€œ  We have argued that drug resistance has tended to evolve faster than vaccine resistance because
column19: drugs are used therapeutically whereas vaccines are used prophylactically
column20: and drugs attack far fewer target sites than do vaccines. This means that drug resistance is more likely to arise in the first place and then spread more rapidly once it has arisen. By contrast
column21: vaccines prevent infection and transmission and induce immunity against many pathogen target sites
column22: making it hard for vaccine resistance to evolve. In the electronic supplementary material
column25: both features have a substantially stronger impact than either alone. The few examples of vaccine-associated evolution detected in human and animal pathogens have occurred against vaccines that lack the benefits of one or both of these features.  â€œ (tagging @why-animals-do-the-thing @seananmcguire @drferox in case they are also interested - this seems up their respective alleys) Â  Honestly this is such a neat article I recommend reading it in its entirety
column26: as it goes into a lot of the differences in action and efficacy between vaccines and antibiotics
column27: and how we can use this going forward to make both vaccines and drugs better.Â   Itâ€™s worth noting that itâ€™s theoretically easier to make a new vaccine too. Target pathogen has evolved so itâ€™s surface proteins have changed? Take the new strain
column28: process it like you did the old one
column29: and you have a new vaccine for that serotype. We can use the same methods to create vaccines again and again. We canâ€™t do that repeatedly for anti-biotics. " False link
